review.title: When Slepian Meets Fiedler: Putting a Focus on the Graph Spectrum
review.abstract: Network models play an important role in studying complex systems in many scientific disciplines. Graph signal processing is receiving growing interest as to design novel tools to combine the analysis of topology and signals. The graph Fourier transform, defined as the eigendecomposition of the graph Laplacian, allows extending conventional signal-processing operations to graphs. One main feature is to let emerge global organization from local interactions; i.e., the Fiedler vector has the smallest non-zero eigenvalue and is key for Laplacian embedding and graph clustering. Here, we introduce the design of Slepian graph signals, by maximizing energy concentration in a predefined subgraph for a given spectral bandlimit. We also establish a link with classical Laplacian embedding and graph clustering, for which the graph Slepian design can serve as a generalization.

INTRODUCTIONGRAPHS are powerful mathematical models to represent complex data structures such as networks [1]. Spectral graph theory supports an important class of methods for studying graph topology and analyzing graph signals. Graph partitioning problems [2] can be solved as a convex relaxation of the graph-section criterion, which returns to the self-decomposition of the graph Laplacian. Thresholding the eigenvector with the smallest non-zero eigenvalue - commonly referred to as a vector by Fiedler - leads to a graph bipartition [3]. These eigenvectors also solve the embedding problem; i.e., mapping the nodes to a line (or higher-dimensional space) so that the distance between connected nodes is minimized.

sections.heading: B. Graph Fourier Spectrum
sections.text: For an undirected weighted graph with N nodes, connectivity is characterized by an N-N symmetrical adjacence matrix A in which the elements Ai, j indicate the edge weights between the nodes i, j = 1,..., N. Here, we assume that the graph is connected and the edge weights are positive. In addition to the graph and its topology, we can also consider graph signals that define an assignment from the nodes to a length-N vector that assigns a value to each node; for example, graph topology can model the presence of communication connections between nodes, while the graph signal can represent measures taken at the nodes. sections.heading: C. Slepians on Graphs
sections.text: To generalize slepians to graphs, we follow the approach of [11], which is based on the introduction of selectivity and bandwidth. Firstly, selectivity can easily be specified by a subset of nodes S containing the NS nodes in which we aim for an optimal energy concentration. Similar to the classic 1-D case, we can represent the subgraph by the selection matrix S. Secondly, we propose to restrict the spectrum to eigenvectors with the NW < N smallest eigenvalues. We can then look at the truncated graph spectrum matrix UW of size N × NW; i.e. any bandlimited graph signal can be represented by g = UWg. sections.heading: IV. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION
sections.text: We proposed two drafts to obtain Slepian graph signals, which can be parameterized by selecting the sub-graph and the bandwidth. The latter provides a handle on the amount of "global" information that can be used to optimize the energy concentration or to embed the distance in the sub-graph. Interestingly, when NW N approaches without selecting the sub-graph, the concentration matrix of the first draft becomes identity, while it is applicable to the conventional laplacian for the second draft.
